title: 110_hr4042
content: The "Family Farm, Small Business, and Home Tax Relief Act" is the short title of the Act. Any amendments or repeals in the Act refer to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, there is an acceleration of the increase in the unified credit. The "Family Farm, Small Business, and Home Tax Relief Act" amends the unified credit against tax by adjusting the applicable credit amount to $3,500,000, with a cost-of-living adjustment for decedents after 2008. The amendment adjusts the cost-of-living adjustment for estates of decedents dying after December 31, 2007. SEC. 3 amends the maximum estate tax rate by removing the 2 highest brackets and applies to estates after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 restores and increases the deduction for family-owned business interests. SEC. 4 restores and increases the deduction for family-owned business interests by amending subsection (j) of section 2057 to apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 2007, with an increase in the deduction amount to $8,000,000. The deduction amount for family-owned business interests is increased to $8,000,000 for estates of decedents dying after 2008. The adjustment is based on the cost-of-living increase and applies to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 2007. SEC. 5. ACCELERATION OF REPEAL OF TAX ON GENERATION-SKIPPING TRANSFERS. Section 2664 is amended to change the termination date from December 31, 2009, to December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. EXCLUSION FROM GROSS ESTATE OF VALUE OF PRINCIPAL RESIDENCE. A new section, SEC. 2059, is added to exclude the value of the principal residence from the gross estate. For US citizens or residents, the taxable estate value is determined by deducting the adjusted value of a residence if it meets certain criteria. This includes being part of the gross estate, located in the US, and used as a principal residence for at least 5 years within an 8-year period before the decedent's death. The deduction allowed under this section is limited to $2,000,000, with a cost-of-living adjustment for decedents dying after 2008. The adjusted value of property is crucial for determining the taxable estate value for US citizens or residents. The value of property for tax purposes is determined by deducting allowable amounts under section 2053(a). The terms "qualified heir" and "member of the family" are defined by section 2032A(e). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 11. The amendments made by this section regarding the principal residence apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 2007.
